title: 107_s832
content: The Act may be cited as the "Indian Gaming Regulatory Improvement Act of 2001" and includes amendments to the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to exclude certain gaming activities from the Gambling Devices Transportation Act. Additionally, amendments are made to section 7 regarding the use of electronic aids in gaming. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to exclude certain gaming activities from the Gambling Devices Transportation Act. Amendments include the addition of a strategic plan requirement for Commission activities, outlining mission statement, goals, objectives, and operational processes. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to exclude certain gaming activities from the Gambling Devices Transportation Act. Amendments include a strategic plan requirement for Commission activities, detailing mission statement, goals, objectives, and operational processes for a period of at least 5 fiscal years. The plan also includes performance goals, identification of external factors affecting goals, and program evaluation descriptions. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to require a strategic plan for Commission activities, updated every 4 years. The plan must align with a performance plan consistent with government performance standards. Consultation with Congress and tribal governments is required in plan development. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to include tribal gaming commissioners, key tribal gaming commission employees, primary management officials, and key employees of the gaming enterprise in oversight. Section 18(a) is revised, section 22 is redesignated as section 25, and a new section is inserted after section 21. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to include tribal gaming commissioners, key tribal gaming commission employees, primary management officials, and key employees of the gaming enterprise in oversight. Section 22 is redesignated as section 25. The Commission shall establish a schedule of fees for gaming operations conducting class II or class III activities regulated by the Act. Fees are based on gross revenues, with a fee of up to 2.5% on the first $1,500,000 and up to 5% on amounts exceeding that. The Commission can impose fees up to $8,000,000 annually, payable quarterly, for services provided to Indian tribes under the Act. The fees must be related to the costs of services and regulations issued by the Commission. The Commission shall promulgate regulations and consult with Indian tribes when establishing a fee schedule for gaming activities. A fee reduction program may be implemented based on the extent of regulation by States or tribes. The Commission will consider various factors when determining the fee schedule for gaming activities, including the unique nature of tribal gaming, the size and scale of tribal gaming activity, and the sovereign rights of Indian tribes. The Commission will establish fee reduction programs for Indian gaming regulation accounts. Regulations will be promulgated as necessary, and consultation with Indian tribes will be required. Fees and civil forfeitures collected will be kept in separate accounts and used only for purposes outlined in the Act. The Commission is responsible for investing funds not needed for immediate expenses in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Obligations can be sold at market price, and special obligations can be redeemed at par plus accrued interest. Credits from interest and proceeds of obligations in the Indian gaming regulatory accounts will be added to and become part of those accounts. SEC. 23. MINIMUM STANDARDS. Indian tribes have exclusive jurisdiction over Class I gaming on their lands, not subject to the Act. For Class II gaming, tribes have primary jurisdiction to regulate activities in accordance with regulations. Similarly, for Class III gaming, tribes have primary jurisdiction to regulate activities authorized under the Act. Rulemaking procedures are outlined for these gaming activities. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Improvement Act of 2001 mandates the Commission to develop regulations for monitoring tribal gaming, internal control systems, and background investigations within 180 days of enactment. Proposed regulations must be published within 1 year. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Improvement Act of 2001 requires the Commission to publish proposed regulations in the Federal Register within 1 year. A negotiated rulemaking committee composed of Federal and Indian tribal government representatives will develop these regulations. Existing regulations on minimum internal control standards will remain in effect. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Improvement Act of 2001 requires the Commission to publish proposed regulations within 1 year. Existing regulations on minimum internal control standards will have no force or effect 1 year after the date of enactment. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Improvement Act of 2001 requires the Commission to publish proposed regulations within 1 year. Existing regulations on minimum internal control standards will have no force or effect 1 year after the date of enactment. SEC. 24 addresses the use of National Indian Gaming Commission civil fines. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Improvement Act of 2001 mandates that funds collected by the Commission are deposited into a separate account for Indian gaming regulation. These funds can be used for grants and technical assistance to Indian tribes for regulatory training, non-gaming economic development, and strategic planning. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Improvement Act of 2001 allows funds collected by the Commission to be used for assisting Indian tribes with programs for problem gamblers, providing other forms of assistance, and consulting with tribal officials. The funds can only be drawn from specific sources and must be authorized in advance by an appropriations Act. The Commission may also create regulations as needed.
